column73: It's the future of the world
column74: Platform for platform building. Core of infrastructure automation and abstracting as much as possible from application. Declarative workloads.

column71: Active member of the k8s community, k8s Slack
column73: Kubernetes is an amazing thing.  Once you get past the overwhelming phase of "getting started" and you begin understanding the moving pieces and workflows- you realized you much you were missing out before it existed.
column74: Continuity, Reliability, Peace of mind.  As an IT engineer with ~12 years of experience, I've been there before the days of k8s, where you had to be very aware of your environment.   Ever since we went all-in with k8s, we're able to focus on the more interesting things, and having to deal with operations less and less.
column75: Kubernetes, once built and managed correctly, is like having a fleet of operators that consistently work for you, 24/7/365, handle the operational side of your application (for the most part) and allows you to focus on the more interesting things.
column76: Reading (a lot), trial and error (a lot), pain, frustration, and eventually- the jackpot. Once you've gotten through the painful parts - you know it was all worth it.
column77: For container orchestration, we tried mesosphere and Docker Swarm before going with k8s, because it was simply the best and most promising one.

column74: deployment flexibility, cloud native, lightweight, open-source
column75: it's like having a house with rooms that expand or contract based on your needs, and you can move around the furniture in the rooms
column76: we have a really old K8s cluster and need to upgrade it quite a few versions to restore stability

column71: So long ago I don't remember

column73: The defacto ecosystem for distributed computing. Huge, healthy open source community that is vendor agnostic. Like Linux, Kubernetes will have a positive contribution to the current and future generations of software engineers. It's been a huge gift.
column74: Kubernetes make it approachable to leverage large collections of CPU, memory, and I/O resources across a cluster to handle increasing customer demands and big data architectures. Kubernetes encapsulates the hard concepts of distributed computing.  It provides many of the "-ilities" that architects seek. Scalability, observability, modularity, deliverability, securability, evolvability, agnostic targets, agnostic connections to services, processing of scoped and unscoped data, distributed data, process and data sharding. The list continues and is long.
column75: I leverage the Kubernetes tool set and community as they are allowing me to deliver results for cloud applications to a large community of users that demand access to lots of data and algorithms. It's ideal for machine learning.
column76: Learn, experiment, talk with others. Remind others that it's a large architecture and requires time, but it's not hard. Learn architecture like microservices first.   Master containers first. As a manager assess your team's "maturity model" and identify gaps before taking on the complexities of a distributed system. If you find Kubernetes frustrating, remember it's just a tool, what is really hard is distributed computing. Kubernetes is making distributed computing more approachable. Remember that Kubernetes is not a turnkey system and it's still at version 1.
column77: Early on I looked at Mesosphere, Nomad, and Swarm. I would never consider a proprietary container orchestrator promoted by a single vendor, or myopic open source project e.g. Docker, ECS, PCF.  Kubernetes filled a growing void, and some other target agnostic open source project might have emerged if it was not for Kubernetes.

column73: Kubernetes is an extensive resource orchestrator, which scales well from small to massive deployments with a vibrant innovative ecosystem.  It's an investment, but a worthwhile one.
column74: I'm trying to ensure the scalability and reliability of container deployments.

column73: The time and knowledge required to maintain a cluster is quite large. The curve to learn is quite steep, but when knowing how to use and/or manage a cluster, it's awesome.  If it was a person with high technical skill or a company with the funds to either hire someone to take care of the cluster or to at the least learn how to deploy to a managed cluster, I would probably say that it's a 10. If it's not, I would probably recommend not to jump in to it due to above reasons.
column74: It's a quickly evolving tool which allows for us to control, monitor and scale the applications, but also automate the whole stack and basically the whole pipeline from testing to production. I can't explain what I'm trying to achieve with it, as I already have! :)

column75: Kubernetes lets us define the state of our applications and their dependencies, then works to make sure that what we tell it remains true. It let's us make statements like there should be 3 copies of our website running and it automatically spreads the load across the 3 copies.
